word: Rome was not slow to inflame their jealous fears. Said the pope to the regent of France in 1523: “This mania [Protestantism] will not only destroy religion, but all principalities, nobilities, laws, orders, and ranks besides.” A few years later a papist dignitary warned the king, “If you wish to preserve your sovereign rights intact; if you wish to keep the nations submitted to you in tranquillity, manfully defend the Catholic faith, and subdue all its enemies by your arms.” And theologians appealed to the prejudices of the people by declaring that the Protestant doctrine “entices men away to novelties and folly; it robs the king of the devoted affection of his subjects, and devastates both Church and State.” Thus Rome succeeded in arraying France against the Reformation. “It was to uphold the throne, preserve the nobles, and maintain the laws, that the sword of persecution was first unsheathed in France.”
